column4: Hey, I'm kind of a noob here but I'm looking at upgrading the kernel in 8.10, I've got the kernel compiled from source, but I'm not sure what step to take next.
use a distro that supports vanilla kernels
because it is unlikely you will get that to work in ubuntu
ubuntu does a lot of patching to their kernel
I see, so I'm probably not going to be able to upgrade the kernel to the latest then?
I would say gentoo or slackware, but there are others
are you actually trying to 2.6.28 kernel??
I believe that is still considered a development release, it is feature in the ubuntu 9.04 if you are feel up to it
that is another thing, vmlinuz and initrd are made for kernels that are not custom compiled.... its just overhead you don't need
sort of makes the kernel "one size fits all"
I'm trying to do this with as little reconstruction of my system as possible, would 9.04 install on top of 8.10 without overwriting to much?
no, and it still beta, it is likely you will run in to issues

when I finished compiling my kernel and ran the sudo make 0=/home/xaero/build/kernel install it installed binaries to the /boot directory, I should just have to add it to grub to get it to boot correct?
Ubuntu comes of with the wierdest, most off the wall ways to accomplish those tasks....
I have never took the time becuase that knowledge does not carry over to other distros and is pretty worthless in ubuntu
but, it is worth a try, just write the grub entry
so basically if I'm trying to get a different kernel for F@H purposes (the kernel that 8.10 comes with lower folding performance DRASTICALLY) I might be better off with a distro switch?
well, that would depend on other needs that you have
should I use the uuid or drop to device names in my grub for my kernel compile?
personaly preference, they both have ther +s and -s, I use the device name
UUIDs can change when moving ports that the drive is plugged in to, device names can change when adding additional devices
